image.altText: A woman in a light blue shirt stands in front of a tree with an Indigenous flag painted into a knot

items.synopsis: Many Yes campaigners have gone into "mourning", joining a collective week of silence, but others are speaking publicly for the first time on the failures of the multi-million dollar campaign.

title.children: 'The No campaign did not win this referendum. It was the Yes campaign that lost it'

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks solemn in a close-up shot.

items.synopsis: The settling of dust after an election can take weeks, sometimes even months. Not so with a referendum, David Speers writes.

title.children: As the political caravan moves on from Indigenous issues, our leaders remain without much of a plan B

image.altText: Israeli tanks and military vehicles.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu convenes Israel's expanded emergency cabinet for the first time, vowing to annihilate the militant group Hamas in retaliation for a rampage by its fighters in Israeli towns.

title.children: Netanyahu convenes emergency Israeli cabinet, vows to 'demolish Hamas'

image.altText: A man, whose faces is obsucred, walks around a concrete area surrounded by high metal fenced walls.

items.synopsis: Adrian's been held for years in solitary confinement without a release date. The public's never seen how he lives until now.

title.children: 'A form of torture': Adrian couldn't stand trial. He's spent the last 11 years locked up with no release date

image.altText: Woman with her young son sitting on a railing on a wharf.

items.synopsis: Having battled with an eating disorder, Renate Ward wanted to make sure her son Luka had a healthy relationship with food. She got that help from Families Tasmania, but others have the same chance, as the not-for-profit enters administration.

title.children: When Renate needed help learning food skills, she got it from Families Tasmania. But others won't

image.altText: A concept artwork showing people walking near buildings and down a street with a stadium seen in the background.

items.synopsis: The Tasmanian government releases a draft plan for the redevelopment of Hobart's Macquarie Point, revealing transportation corridors and how developments will fit around a massive central stadium.

title.children: How 'rapid buses' will bring fans to Hobart AFL stadium and Macquarie Point precinct revealed in draft plan

image.altText: A composite image of Joe Biden, Benjamin Netanyahu and Vladimir Putin

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin would be relishing the way that the Israel-Gaza war has knocked Ukraine from international consciousness, writes John Lyons.

title.children: The biggest winner of the Israel-Gaza war may just be Vladimir Putin

image.altText: Sam Neill leans against glass sliding doors of an apartment

items.synopsis: Sam Neill opens up about why he's "not really interested" in his cancer and why the thought of retirement is "horrifying".

title.children: 'I'm not frightened of dying but I'd be annoyed': Sam Neill is in remission. This is what he's learnt about life

image.altText: Amani Francois, Rekisha Satour and Conor Bowden.

items.synopsis: With six Australian states and territories delivering a resounding No vote to an Indigenous Voice to Parliament, young First Nations people reflect on what comes next.

title.children: 'This referendum will affect us the most': Young First Nations voters reflect on No vote

image.altText: An illustration showing two hexagons with the words No and Yes on them

items.synopsis: Scratch the surface of the Voice referendum results, and a more complicated picture emerges.

title.children: Scratch the surface of the Voice results, and a more complicated picture emerges

image.altText: Anthony Albanese speaks in front of the Australian, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags inside parliament house

items.synopsis: This referendum will likely have hundreds, if not thousands, of untold stories about the toll it has taken on First Nations people. There's no denying it will have political implications, too, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: Albanese will have questions to answer over the Voice, but the result also raises concerns for the opposition

image.altText: Two Afghan cricket players embrace after winning a cricket match

items.synopsis: England's title defence at the Cricket World Cup is in real trouble after losing to Afghanistan by 69 runs in one of the biggest shocks in the tournament's history.

title.children: England suffers stunning loss to minnow Afghanistan, putting Cricket World Cup title defence in jeopardy

image.altText: Tim Tszyu walks to the ring

items.synopsis: It is likely Tim Tszyu will not fight on Australian soil for some time, with a Las Vegas date in mind for the WBO super welterweight champion, who has so many options as he strives for immortality, writes Simon Smale.

title.children: Tim Tszyu is on the path to greatness — and Las Vegas super fights are the next stop

image.altText: Women hold signs reading "Gaza cease fire now!" and "no one is free unless Palestine is" at Hyde Park

items.synopsis: There were no arrests and no major incidents at rallies in three Australian capital cities, which took place after a week of tension between organisers and authorities in New South Wales.

title.children: Thousands turn out for pro-Palestinian rallies in Melbourne and Sydney after week of tension

image.altText: A girl sits on the stairs and looks sad as she looks at her phone

items.synopsis: Group chats are more popular than ever, and offer a more intimate form of conversation compared to social media. But unclear rules of engagement can lead to problems.

title.children: If your group chat is anxiety-inducing, you're not alone. Here are tips to help

image.altText: A young woman with a nose ring and long, dyed hair leans on a fence in her backyard.

items.synopsis: With the clock ticking on her lease, 37-year-old Prudence McGuire was desperate for help. When she turned to the government for assistance, she received a devastating response — but one that led to an 11th-hour intervention.

title.children: Woman with cystic fibrosis on brink of homelessness told to start calling caravan parks

image.altText: A close up of a woman's hands with a stack of ballot papers next to her, with a lot of elastic bands near by.

items.synopsis: As Yes supporters label yesterday's swift rejection of an Indigenous Voice to Parliament a "kick in the guts", a clearer picture emerges of the parts WA where the concept was least accepted.

title.children: How the Voice echoed differently in WA: A look at the results from north to south

image.altText: A composite image of three women and a man.

items.synopsis: Not a single Queensland electorate outside of the state's south-east voted to support the referendum, and the firmest of those against it all fall within Queensland. We ask voters why.

title.children: In the parts of Queensland where the No vote was strongest, voters reflect on the referendum

image.altText: Toddler in a hospital bed wearing casts on hands and legs after surgery.

items.synopsis: Last Christmas, Broken Hill toddler Ryan Lines was fighting for his life after his body went into septic shock due to a bacterial infection. Ten months on, he's adjusting to his new life while his family aims to spread more awareness about the condition and what to look out for.

title.children: He fought for his life and underwent multiple amputations, but Ryan is still his 'cheeky' self

image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: Results so far show that voters in the territory's Indigenous remote communities voted heavily in favour of yes. So what happens now?

title.children: The NT voted No to the Voice, but results show remote communities backed Yes

image.altText: A woman sits in a pasture with cows behind her.

items.synopsis: After watching her farm narrowly survive the inferno of Black Summer and welcoming a grandson into the world, Rachel Ward knew it was time to try to do things differently.

title.children: 'Everybody has to change the paddock between their ears': Aussie actor finds homegrown hope

image.altText: A map of Australia against a background of orange and purple stripes.

items.synopsis: Australia has voted No in the referendum, but the vote hasn't been uniform across states and cities. A small number of electorates, mainly in inner cities, are projected to have voted Yes.

title.children: A clear pattern has emerged in the way cities have voted in this referendum

image.altText: a surfer with his surfboard on the floor votes at a polling centre in  bondi for the indigenous voice to parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Support for Yes was strongest in the inner suburbs, while the majority of outer suburban, regional and rural voters said No. But analysts say the reasons why voters rejected the referendum question is more complex.

title.children: Voice result reveals more than just Australia's country-city divide

image.altText: A hand placing a ballot in a voting box.

items.synopsis: The New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council is holding "a week of silence" to mourn the outcome of the referendum, as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags are lowered to half-mast.

title.children: AEC rejects suggestions of interference at remote polls, as Indigenous leaders start 'week of silence' — as it happened

image.altText: A person pouring coffee and milk into a white coffee cup to make latte art.

items.synopsis: Most people gain small amounts of weight each year as they age. But can coffee help prevent this gradual weight gain?

title.children: Can coffee help you avoid putting on weight as you age?

image.altText: A dove is silhouetted against a partially-blocked sun

items.synopsis: An annular eclipse darkened skies over several South American countries and the US, but it wasn't visible in Australia. Here are the photos from the other side of the globe.

title.children: 'Ring of fire' solar eclipse dazzles in the US and South America

image.altText: A close up, blurry photo of a man with a moustache and brown eyes.

items.synopsis: The Israel Defense Forces' top spokesman says the killing of senior Hamas members is a "top priority". But analysts say tracking down these leaders will be complicated, and even if Israel is able to "eliminate" its targets, there is no guarantee it will bring an end to this war.

title.children: 'Hamas is underground, it lives in tunnels': Why the hunt for Mohammed Deif could destroy Gaza

image.altText: Piper Laurie with red hair looking at the camera and leaning against the wall with her hands together

items.synopsis: The Oscar-nominated actor, who performed in acclaimed roles such as Carrie and at one point abandoned acting altogether in search of a "more meaningful" life, has died aged 91.

title.children: Three-time Oscar nominee and Twin Peaks actress Piper Laurie dies

image.altText: Chris Hipkins bows his head while standing at the lectern.

items.synopsis: New Zealand Labour took a step to the centre, and its supporters walked in the opposite directions, writes Emily Clark.

title.children: As Australia rejects the Voice, NZ swings towards Te Pāti Māori

image.altText: Shoppers watch on as firefighters in a cherry picker douse a fire from above

items.synopsis: The Country Fire Service said it was too early to determine what caused the fire, but said there had been reports of aerosol canisters "exploding".

title.children: Shoppers evacuated as Adelaide Hills supermarket gutted by fire

image.altText: A close-up of a person's hands writing in a book on a desk, with a croissant and coffee nearby

items.synopsis: The idea of improving my wellbeing without significant effort seemed too good to be true, until I gave it a go.

title.children: How creating a 'to-don't' list gave me some much-needed mental space

image.altText: an old black and white photo of a group of children with men either side holding a very long black snake

items.synopsis: When Europeans colonised Tasmania they developed a hysterical fear of snakes but unwittingly provided them with the perfect food source, rabbits, which led to one venomous species growing into near 2-metre giants.

title.children: Bounties, gruesome treatments and the creation of giants: Welcome to Tasmania's violent past with snakes
